skills.name: Write a recurring decimal with a single digit recurring pattern as a fraction (US)
Write a fraction with a single digit denominator as a recurring decimal (US)

explanations.A: It seems like you've just given the digit as the denominator here, but ½ is the same as 0.5. This decimal is 0.222222222...
explanations.B: Not quite, this fraction would give us the decimal 0.22, but this is 0.2 recurring which is 0.2222222222 (ongoing forever!).
explanations.C: Not quite, this would be the decimal 0.2 but the bar on top of the 2 tells us that the 2 is recurring, so we actually want a fraction that represents 0.22222222... (going on forever).

explanations.B: Not quite, this would be the decimal 0.4 but the bar on top of the 4 tells us that the 4 is recurring, so we actually want a fraction that represents 0.44444444444... (going on forever).
explanations.C: Not quite, this fraction would give us the decimal 0.44, but this is 0.4 recurring which is 0.444444444444 (ongoing forever!).
explanations.D: It seems like you've just given the digit as the denominator here, but ¹/₄ is the same as 0.25. This decimal is 0.44444444444...

explanations.A: 0.555555555... (where the 5 goes on forever) can be written as ⁵/₉. 5 ÷ 9 = .555...
explanations.B: It looks like you have just put the digits of the fraction below a recurring sign. If you divide 5 by 9, you don't get 0.59 recurring.
explanations.C: I think you have just put the numerator and the denominator together as a decimal. This is not the same as dividing 5 by 9.
explanations.D: Not quite! Here I think you've just written the numerator as the decimal. The decimal needs to be the result of 5 divided by 9 which gives a never ending decimal.

explanations.A: It looks like you have just put the digits of the fraction below a recurring sign. If you divide 8 by 9, you don't get 0.89 recurring.
explanations.B: 0.88888888... (where the 8 goes on forever) can be written as 8/9. 8 ÷ 9 = .888...
explanations.C: Not quite! Here I think you've just written the numerator as the decimal. The decimal needs to be the result of 8 divided by 9 which gives a never ending decimal.
explanations.D: I think you have just put the numerator and the denominator together as a decimal. This is not the same as dividing 8 by 9.

explanations.A: You're close! You just need to remember to write the fraction in its simplest form.
explanations.B: 0.44444444444... (where the 4 goes on forever) can be written as ⁴/₉. x = .444... 10x = 4.444... 10x - x = 4.444... - .444... 9x = 4 x = ⁴/₉
explanations.C: I think here, you have turned 0.4 into a fraction rather than 0.4 recurring.
explanations.D: I think you have found an equivalent fraction to 0.4 rather than the recurring decimal 0.44444444...

explanations.A: You're close! You just need to remember to write the fraction in its simplest form.
explanations.B: I think here, you have turned 0.7 into a fraction rather than 0.7 recurring.
explanations.C: 0.77777777... (where the 7 goes on forever) can be written as ⁷/₉. x = .777... 10x = 7.777... 10x - x = 7.777... - .777... 9x = 7 x = ⁷/₉
explanations.D: I think you have found an equivalent fraction to 0.7 rather than the recurring decimal 0.77777777....

explanations.A: It looks like you have just put the digits of the fraction below a recurring sign. If you divide 7 by 9, you don't get 0.79 recurring.
explanations.B: I think you have just put the numerator and the denominator together as a decimal. This is not the same as dividing 7 by 9.
explanations.C: 0.77777777777... (where the 7 goes on forever) can be written as ⁷/₉. 7 ÷ 9 = .777...
explanations.D: I think you have written the digits to the fraction as a decimal and assumed just the 9 recurs. We need to think about dividing the numerator by the denominator to work out the recurring decimal.

explanations.A: I think you have just put the numerator and the denominator together as a decimal. This is not the same as dividing 5 by 9.
explanations.B: 0.55555555... (where the 5 goes on forever) can be written as ⁵/₉. 5 ÷ 9 = .555...
explanations.C: It looks like you have just put the digits of the fraction below a recurring sign. If you divide 5 by 9, you don't get 0.59 recurring.
explanations.D: I think you have written the digits of the fraction as a decimal and assumed just the 9 recurs. We need to think about dividing the numerator by the denominator to work out the recurring decimal.

explanations.A: Not quite! It looks like you haven't recognised that ⅓ and ³/₉ are equivalent fractions, and so would make the same decimal.
explanations.B: I think you have assumed here that because Tom's fraction doesn't have a denominator of 9, it can't be a recurring decimal but this isn't the case.
explanations.C: 0.3333333333... (where the 3 goes on forever) can be written as both ³/₉ and ⅓ as they are equivalent fractions, so both Tom and Katie are correct.
explanations.D: To find a recurring decimal, we need to think about dividing the numerator by the denominator. As ⅓ and ³/₉ are equivalent fractions, we would get the same decimal when we convert them.

explanations.A: It looks like you have written the denominator of the fraction as the digit after the decimal place. This doesn't give us the equivalent decimal to the fraction. ¹/₆ is less than a half, and a half as a decimal is 0.5, so 0.6 would be too big.
explanations.B: 0.66666666... (where the 6 goes on forever) can be written as ⁶/₉ but not as ¹/₆ as they are not equivalent fractions, so both only Katie is correct.
explanations.C: Not quite! It looks like you think that ¹/₆ and ⁶/₉ are equivalent fractions, and so would make the same decimal. This is false, they are not equivalent fractions, so they wouldn't make the same decimal.
explanations.D: To find a recurring decimal, we need to think about dividing the numerator by the denominator. As ¹/₆ and ⁶/₉ are not equivalent fractions, we would not get the same decimal when we convert them.
